patterns.name: useApiKeyManager
patterns.description: Hook for useApiKeyManager
patterns.usage: Handles the lifecycle of Orderly API keys, including generation, retrieval, and revocation. Essential for building user settings pages where users manage their bot access or third-party integrations.
notes: Always refresh the key list (getApiKeys) immediately after creating or deleting a key to keep the UI in sync.
Handle the isLoading state carefully, as key generation involves cryptographic operations that may take a moment.
Be explicit with scopes (e.g., 'read' vs 'trade') to ensure the principle of least privilege for user security.

patterns.name: useApiStatusActions
patterns.description: Hook for useApiStatusActions
patterns.usage: Provides actions to control and monitor the connection status to the Orderly Network API. Useful for implementing global connection indicators, health checks, or handling maintenance modes.
notes: This hook returns actions, not just state; use it to trigger events like reconnection or health checks.
It is often used in conjunction with a status selector to display the current state (connected/disconnected) to the user.
Use setMaintenanceMode to gracefully block user actions when the network is scheduled for downtime.

patterns.name: useDataCenterContext
patterns.description: Hook for useDataCenterContext
patterns.usage: This hook exposes the Data Center, which acts as a local cache for market configurations, symbol metadata, and other static data required for trading operations.
notes: Useful for retrieving trading rules (min order size, tick size) before placing orders.
Avoids redundant API calls by keeping market configuration data in context.
Helper functions like `getSymbolInfo` are commonly exposed here.

patterns.name: useCommission
patterns.description: Hook for useCommission
patterns.usage: Retrieves commission statistics for the connected user, specifically focusing on the trading volume generated which determines commission levels or payouts.
notes: Returns a `volume` property, usually representing the 30-day or total volume.
Data is often used to calculate VIP tiers or referral rebate percentages.
Requires the user to be part of the referral program to return meaningful data.

patterns.name: useRefereeInfo
patterns.description: Hook for useRefereeInfo
patterns.usage: Retrieves a list of accounts (referees) that have been referred by the currently connected wallet. This is used for tracking referral network growth.
notes: Returns an array of referee objects containing details like registration date or status.
Useful for building a 'Referral Dashboard' to show network size.
May return an empty array if the user has not referred anyone yet.

patterns.name: useAllBrokers
patterns.description: Hook for useAllBrokers
patterns.usage: Fetches a comprehensive list of all brokers registered within the Orderly Network. This is essential for onboarding flows where a user needs to select or switch between different broker partners.
notes: The returned data typically includes broker IDs, names, and metadata like logos.
This data is relatively static, so it is often cached aggressively by the SDK.
Useful for building a 'Switch Broker' interface or displaying partner attribution.

patterns.name: useCurEpochEstimate
patterns.description: Hook for useCurEpochEstimate
patterns.usage: Calculates and returns the estimated trading rewards or fee rebates a user will receive for the current epoch (time period). It factors in trading volume and holding tiers.
notes: The estimate is dynamic and updates as the user trades or epoch parameters change.
Returns '0' or null if the user has no activity in the current epoch.
Do not use this for final payout logic; it is purely for estimation/UI display.

patterns.name: useCalculatorService
patterns.description: Hook for useCalculatorService
patterns.usage: Provides a utility service for performing complex trading calculations. This includes estimating total cost, price impact, and margin requirements before an order is placed.
notes: This hook returns a service object, not just data. You call methods on it.
Essential for building 'Order Preview' modals to show users exactly what they will spend.
Calculations are based on current order book depth and market conditions.

patterns.name: useConfig
patterns.description: Hook for useConfig
patterns.usage: Reads the global configuration object passed to the OrderlyProvider. It contains environment variables, API endpoints, and feature flags necessary for the SDK to function.
notes: Values are read-only at the component level; they are set when initializing the app.
Useful for conditional rendering based on the environment (e.g., Testnet vs Mainnet).
Contains domain settings for API endpoints.

patterns.name: useDatabaseInitialization
patterns.description: Hook for useDatabaseInitialization
patterns.usage: Manages the initialization of the local IndexedDB used by Orderly for caching order history, balances, and account settings to improve performance and offline capability.
notes: Must be checked before trying to access historical data or local cache.
Usually runs once on application mount.
If initialization fails, the app may need to prompt the user to clear site data.

patterns.name: useEventEmitter
patterns.description: Hook for useEventEmitter
patterns.usage: Provides access to the Orderly SDK's event bus. It allows components to subscribe to real-time events such as order updates, account changes, or socket connection status.
notes: Always remove event listeners in the useEffect cleanup to prevent memory leaks.
Crucial for real-time UI updates without constantly polling the API.
Common events include 'ACCOUNT_UPDATE', 'ORDER_FILLED', and 'POSITION_UPDATE'.

patterns.name: useFeeState
patterns.description: Hook for useFeeState
patterns.usage: Retrieves the current fee rates applicable to the user's account. These rates often change based on trading volume, staking tiers, or holding specific tokens.
notes: Returns rates as decimals (e.g., 0.0005 for 0.05%), usually requiring formatting for display.
Updates automatically when the user's volume tier changes.
Useful for calculating precise costs in the trade preview.

patterns.name: useKeyStore
patterns.description: Hook for useKeyStore
patterns.usage: Handles the storage and retrieval of the user's private key (or scoped key) used to sign transactions. It abstracts the security logic of keeping keys accessible only to the SDK.
notes: This hook interacts with the browser's secure storage (LocalStorage/SessionStorage depending on implementation).
Never log the raw keyStore object to the console in production.
It is the bridge between the user's wallet (like MetaMask) and the Orderly off-chain signing.

patterns.name: useNetworkInfo
patterns.description: Hook for useNetworkInfo
patterns.usage: Retrieves information about the currently connected blockchain network. This is essential for ensuring the user's wallet is connected to the correct chain (e.g., Arbitrum Sepolia vs Mainnet) supported by Orderly.
notes: Use this hook to validate that the user's wallet is on the correct chain before allowing transactions.
The `info` object often contains metadata like the chain name, native currency symbol, and RPC URL.
It automatically reacts to wallet network changes (e.g., user switching networks in MetaMask).

patterns.name: useParamsCheck
patterns.description: Hook for useParamsCheck
patterns.usage: Validates trading parameters (such as price, quantity, and symbol) against Orderly's requirements locally before making a network request. This helps prevent unnecessary API errors.
notes: Performs client-side validation to catch user input errors instantly.
Reduces load on the API by rejecting malformed requests early in the UI flow.
Always pair this with backend validation, but use this for immediate UI feedback.

patterns.name: usePoster
patterns.description: Hook for usePoster
patterns.usage: A utility hook for sending authenticated HTTP POST requests to the Orderly API. It handles the complexities of signing requests with the user's private key (or broker key) automatically.
notes: Abstracts away the cryptographic signing process required for private endpoints.
Essential for any write operations such as placing orders, canceling orders, or updating leverage.
Ensure the user is authenticated (via useAccount) before calling this to avoid signature errors.

patterns.name: usePreLoadData
patterns.description: Hook for usePreLoadData
patterns.usage: Manages the initial data fetching phase of the application. It ensures that critical data (like account info, allowances, and config) is loaded before the main interface is rendered.
notes: Prevents the UI from rendering in a broken state while essential data is still fetching.
Returns a `done` boolean to easily toggle loading spinners or splash screens.
Handles global initialization errors gracefully so the app can display a fallback UI.

patterns.name: useRestrictedInfo
patterns.description: Hook for useRestrictedInfo
patterns.usage: Checks if the user's IP address or jurisdiction falls under restricted regions (e.g., OFAC sanctioned countries). This is crucial for compliance (KYC/AML) in DeFi applications.
notes: Automatically detects the user's region based on their IP address.
Use this to block access to specific features or the entire application to remain compliant.
It is a read-only check; blocking the UI is the responsibility of the developer.

patterns.name: useTrack
patterns.description: Hook for useTrack
patterns.usage: A helper hook for tracking user events and analytics. It standardizes how events are sent to the analytics provider configured within the Orderly SDK.
notes: Standardizes event tracking across the application, making analytics consistent.
Useful for monitoring user behavior, conversion funnels, and debugging UI interactions.
Accepts an event name and a payload object for custom metadata.

patterns.name: useTrackingInstance
patterns.description: Hook for useTrackingInstance
patterns.usage: Provides direct access to the underlying analytics instance (e.g., Segment, Google Analytics) used by the SDK. This allows for advanced analytics operations beyond simple event tracking.
notes: Use this when you need low-level control over the analytics library (e.g., group identification, aliasing).
Allows you to integrate custom plugins or middleware into the analytics pipeline.
Ensure the instance exists before calling methods to avoid runtime errors.

patterns.name: useOrderEntry
patterns.description: Hook for useOrderEntry
patterns.usage: A legacy hook for handling order submission logic. It manages the local state of an order form and provides a function to submit the order to the Orderly Network.
notes: This hook is deprecated; prefer the newer store-based hooks (useOrderStore) for better state management and performance.
It combines form state and submission logic, which can make testing harder compared to separating concerns.
Ensure you check if the order type is 'LIMIT' before including the price field in the submission payload.

patterns.name: useOrderEntryFromStore
patterns.description: Hook for useOrderEntryFromStore
patterns.usage: Reads the global state of the order entry form (symbol, price, amount, side, etc.) from the central store. Ideal for summary components or validation logic that needs to react to form changes.
notes: This is a read-heavy hook; use it to display data. For modifying inputs, prefer useOrderStore or specific actions.
It automatically subscribes to store updates, ensuring the UI re-renders whenever the order form changes.
Useful for calculating derived values (like total cost or margin requirements) in real-time as the user types.

patterns.name: useOrderEntity
patterns.description: Hook for useOrderEntity
patterns.usage: Provides metadata about the current order entity, specifically the maximum quantity (`maxQty`) and the current `symbol`. This is critical for input validation and UI constraints.
notes: Use maxQty to set the 'max' attribute on HTML inputs or to validate form data before submission.
The symbol returned reflects the currently selected trading pair in the order entry store.
This hook helps prevent API errors caused by submitting orders larger than the allowed limit for the specific asset.

patterns.name: useOrderStore
patterns.description: Hook for useOrderStore
patterns.usage: Provides actions to mutate the global order entry state. This is the primary way to update form fields (symbol, side, price, amount) from your UI components.
notes: Separate your read components (using useOrderEntryFromStore) from your write components (using useOrderStore) for cleaner architecture.
The resetOrder action is useful for clearing the form after a successful submission or when switching trading pairs.
Actions update the global Zustand store, meaning changes are instantly reflected across all components subscribed to that state.

patterns.name: useMarketTradeStream
patterns.description: Hook for useMarketTradeStream
patterns.usage: Subscribes to a WebSocket feed of individual trade fills (taker trades) for a specific market. This provides a real-time list of the most recent transactions occurring on the order book.
notes: Returns an array of trade objects, usually ordered by most recent first.
Updates in real-time via WebSocket connection managed by the SDK.
Essential for building 'Recent Trades' or 'Market Activity' components.

patterns.name: useOrderStream
patterns.description: Hook for useOrderStream
patterns.usage: Maintains a real-time list of the user's orders (open, filled, or canceled) by subscribing to the private WebSocket channel. It keeps the local state in sync with the exchange order book.
notes: Requires an authenticated session (API key or Wallet).
Automatically handles order status updates (e.g., 'NEW' to 'FILLED') without polling.
The primary data source for the 'Open Orders' and 'Order History' UI components.

patterns.name: useOrderbookStream
patterns.description: Hook for useOrderbookStream
patterns.usage: Establishes a websocket connection to receive real-time depth (orderbook) data for a specific trading pair. It returns two-dimensional arrays representing price and quantity levels.
notes: The returned arrays (asks/bids) are typically sorted: Asks ascending (lowest sell), Bids descending (highest buy).
Data updates automatically on every market tick; no manual polling is required.
Use the symbol argument to ensure you are receiving data for the correct market (e.g., 'PERP_ETH_USDC').

patterns.name: useOrderlyContext
patterns.description: Hook for useOrderlyContext
patterns.usage: Provides access to the core Orderly SDK context. This is the primary way to access global application state such as the connected wallet address, broker ID, account ID, and the current network environment.
notes: This is a context hook, so it must be used within a component wrapped by `OrderlyProvider`.
Useful for conditional rendering based on connection status or account ID.
Contains the `domain` setting which is crucial for determining if you are on testnet or mainnet.

patterns.name: usePositionClose
patterns.description: Hook for usePositionClose
patterns.usage: A specialized hook to handle the closing of open trading positions. It simplifies the logic of placing a market order to reduce an existing position to zero.
notes: This hook abstracts away the complexity of calculating the opposite order required to flatten a position.
The isClosing state is crucial for UX, preventing the user from spamming the close button while the transaction is processing.
Always confirm with the user before closing, as this is an irreversible financial action.

patterns.name: usePositionStream
patterns.description: Hook for usePositionStream
patterns.usage: Subscribes to the user's private position data via websocket. It provides real-time Profit and Loss (PnL) metrics, including total unrealized PnL and Return on Investment (ROI) across all open positions.
notes: Requires the user to be connected/authenticated with the Orderly SDK.
Values update in real-time as mark prices and funding rates change.
Useful for dashboard headers or portfolio summary widgets where live PnL tracking is critical.

patterns.name: useAccountInfo
patterns.description: Hook for useAccountInfo
patterns.usage: Fetches and returns the user's account information, such as total equity, account value, and available balance. This is essential for displaying portfolio health and buying power.
notes: The data usually updates in real-time or near real-time via WebSocket connections managed by the SDK.
Handle the isLoading state to prevent layout shifts or displaying '0' while data is being fetched on initial load.
Use availableBalance to validate if a user has sufficient funds before allowing an order submission.

patterns.name: useSubAccountAlgoOrderStream
patterns.description: Hook for useSubAccountAlgoOrderStream
patterns.usage: Subscribes to the stream of algorithmic orders (such as Take-Profit, Stop-Loss, or Trailing Stops) associated with a specific sub-account ID.
notes: Specifically targets 'algo' orders, distinct from standard limit/market orders handled by `useOrderStream`.
Requires the `accountId` (sub-account ID) to filter the stream correctly.
Critical for managing risk strategies and conditional order visibility.

patterns.name: useWalletSubscription
patterns.description: Hook for useWalletSubscription
patterns.usage: Maintains a WebSocket connection to listen for changes in the user's wallet state, including balance updates from trades, deposits, or withdrawals.
notes: This provides a holistic view of the account, including `total_equity` and `unrealized_pnl`.
It automatically reconnects if the socket drops, ensuring the UI stays synced with the server.
Use this to update the header bar or dashboard summary in real-time.

patterns.name: useWalletTopic
patterns.description: Hook for useWalletTopic
patterns.usage: This hook manages the WebSocket subscription to the private wallet topic. It is essential for receiving real-time updates on the user's asset balances and portfolio changes without manual polling.
notes: Requires an active Orderly Key and wallet connection to subscribe to private data.
Automatically handles reconnection logic if the WebSocket drops.
Returns the raw data payload, which you may need to parse or format for display.

patterns.name: useSubAccountDataObserver
patterns.description: Hook for useSubAccountDataObserver
patterns.usage: Monitors the asset holdings of a specific sub-account in real-time. It returns a 'holding' array or object representing the assets and their quantities within that sub-account.
notes: Requires a valid `subAccountId` (integer) passed as an argument.
Updates automatically via WebSocket when the sub-account trades or transfers funds.
Useful for portfolio management views across multiple accounts.

patterns.name: useSubAccountMaxWithdrawal
patterns.description: Hook for useSubAccountMaxWithdrawal
patterns.usage: Determines the maximum amount of a specific token that can be withdrawn from a sub-account, taking into account margin requirements and open positions.
notes: Essential for risk management to prevent over-withdrawing which could cause liquidation.
Requires both the `subAccountId` and the `token` symbol (e.g., 'USDC', 'ETH').
The value changes dynamically based on market prices and position sizes.

patterns.name: useSubAccountWS
patterns.description: Hook for useSubAccountWS
patterns.usage: Handles the WebSocket connection lifecycle for sub-account specific data. It ensures that the client is listening to the correct channels for sub-account updates.
notes: Abstracts the complexity of subscribing to specific sub-account topics.
Useful for ensuring connection status before rendering sensitive trading data.
Often used internally by other sub-account hooks, but can be used for UI status indicators.

patterns.name: useAccountRewardsHistory
patterns.description: Hook for useAccountRewardsHistory
patterns.usage: Retrieves the history of trading rewards claimed by the user. The data is organized by 'epochs' (specific time periods for reward campaigns) and associated brokers.
notes: Returns an array of historical records, each containing `epoch_id` and `broker`.
Useful for auditing past rewards or displaying a 'Rewards History' page.
May require pagination if the history is extensive.

patterns.name: useAccount
patterns.description: Hook for useAccount
patterns.usage: Core hook for managing the user's account state. It distinguishes between Main and Sub-accounts and provides methods to create new accounts or refresh account data from the server.
notes: isMainAccount is a boolean flag to toggle UI features specific to the main wallet.
The refresh function is vital to sync local state after on-chain transactions.
create() handles the logic for generating a new sub-account ID linked to the main account.

patterns.name: usePortfolio
patterns.description: Hook for usePortfolio
patterns.usage: Retrieves the user's full portfolio composition, including individual token holdings and their USD values. Ideal for dashboard views showing asset allocation.
notes: The portfolio structure often contains a 'holding' array which lists individual assets like USDC, ETH, etc.
This hook aggregates data across different sub-accounts or chains if applicable to the Orderly configuration.
Use this data to calculate percentages for a pie chart visualization of asset allocation.

patterns.name: useStatisticsDaily
patterns.description: Hook for useStatisticsDaily
patterns.usage: Provides a daily snapshot of trading performance. It aggregates total volume, net PnL, and ROI, making it perfect for dashboard summary widgets.
notes: Returns `vol`, `pnl`, and `roi` as the primary metrics.
Data is typically aggregated for the current day or the most recent 24-hour period.
Useful for giving users a quick health check of their daily trading activity.

patterns.name: useBalanceSubscription
patterns.description: Hook for useBalanceSubscription
patterns.usage: Maintains a real-time subscription to the user's account balance. It updates instantly upon trade execution, fee deduction, or deposit, without requiring a page refresh.
notes: Uses WebSocket connections under the hood for low-latency updates.
Returns a balance object containing `total_equity`, `available_balance`, and `margin_balance`.
Must be used within an Orderly Provider context and requires an authenticated session.

patterns.name: useChain
patterns.description: Hook for useChain
patterns.usage: Identifies the active blockchain network the SDK is currently configured to interact with. This is vital for multi-chain dApps to ensure transactions are signed for the correct chain.
notes: Returns `chain_name` (string), such as 'arbitrum' or 'optimism'.
Use this to conditionally render chain-specific UI elements (e.g., different bridge addresses).
Relies on the OrderlyProvider's configuration; ensure the provider is set up correctly.

patterns.name: useChainInfo
patterns.description: Hook for useChainInfo
patterns.usage: Provides detailed metadata about the current blockchain, such as the Chain ID, RPC URL, and Block Explorer URL. It is best used for generating links or configuring web3 providers.
notes: Returns an object with `chain_id`, `rpc_url`, `explorer_url`, and `native_currency`.
Essential for constructing valid transaction links or debugging network connection issues.
Pairs well with `useChain` when you need both the name and the configuration details.

patterns.name: useChains
patterns.description: Hook for useChains
patterns.usage: Retrieves the list of supported blockchain networks configured in the Orderly SDK, categorized by environment (testnet vs mainnet). This is essential for building network switchers or validating connection targets.
notes: Returns an object with two keys: `testnet` and `mainnet`, each containing an array of chain objects.
Chain objects typically include `id`, `name`, and `rpc_url` required for wallet connections.
Useful for dynamically generating dropdown menus for wallet connection flows.

patterns.name: useComputedLTV
patterns.description: Hook for useComputedLTV
patterns.usage: Calculates real-time Loan-to-Value (LTV) components for a specific asset or position. It breaks down the calculation into quantity, current index price, and the asset's risk weight.
notes: Essential for building margin calculators or liquidation risk UI components.
Relies on real-time oracle data for `indexPrice`.
The `weight` return value is crucial for understanding how much collateral value this specific asset contributes.

patterns.name: useConvert
patterns.description: Hook for useConvert
patterns.usage: Provides functionality to convert one asset to another within the Orderly ecosystem (e.g., swapping stablecoins or managing collateral types).
notes: Handles the transaction execution for token conversion on-chain.
Returns loading and error states to manage UI feedback during the swap.
Ensure the user has sufficient balance of the `fromToken` before calling.

patterns.name: useFundingDetails
patterns.description: Hook for useFundingDetails
patterns.usage: Provides granular information about the funding state of a perpetual market, including timestamps for the next funding event and predicted rates.
notes: Helps traders predict upcoming costs or payments for holding positions.
Includes timing data (`nextFundingTime`) to display countdowns.
Distinct from historical rates; focuses on the current and immediate future state.

patterns.name: useFundingRate
patterns.description: Hook for useFundingRate
patterns.usage: Fetches the current funding rate for a specific perpetual market symbol. This is the primary rate used to calculate fees paid or received by traders.
notes: Returns the raw rate value (usually requiring multiplication by 100 for percentage display).
Often includes `markPrice` and `indexPrice` as they are used to calculate the rate.
Updates frequently (often every few seconds) to reflect market conditions.

patterns.name: useFundingRates
patterns.description: Hook for useFundingRates
patterns.usage: Fetches the current funding rates for all perpetual markets in a single call. This is optimized for dashboard views showing multiple assets.
notes: Returns an object or array mapping symbols to their current funding data.
More efficient than calling `useFundingRate` multiple times for different symbols.
Data is usually aggregated, making it perfect for overview lists.

patterns.name: useFundingRatesStore
patterns.description: Hook for useFundingRatesStore
patterns.usage: Provides direct access to the global funding rates state store (Zustand). This is useful for accessing cached data without triggering network requests or for creating highly optimized components.
notes: Reads from a global state store, ensuring instant UI updates when data changes elsewhere.
Does not typically trigger its own fetch; relies on other hooks (like `useFundingRates`) to populate the store.
Best used for performance-critical components like tickers or real-time headers.

patterns.name: useFutures
patterns.description: Hook for useFutures
patterns.usage: Retrieves the list of all available futures/perpetual markets along with their static configuration (min order size, tick size) and dynamic data (mark price, volume).
notes: The primary source of truth for which symbols are available to trade.
Contains validation parameters (e.g., `min_order_size`) required for order forms.
Returns a comprehensive array suitable for building market selection tables.

patterns.name: useInternalTransfer
patterns.description: Hook for useInternalTransfer
patterns.usage: Handles the logic for transferring assets between the user's connected wallet and their Orderly trading account (or between sub-accounts). It manages the transaction state and execution.
notes: Usually requires the user to have approved the Orderly contract to spend tokens (allowance) if transferring from the wallet.
The `isLoading` state is critical for UI feedback to prevent double-spending or user confusion during blockchain confirmation.
Always wrap the transfer call in a try/catch block to handle network errors or insufficient balance scenarios.

patterns.name: useMaintenanceStatus
patterns.description: Hook for useMaintenanceStatus
patterns.usage: Checks the operational status of the Orderly Network. It returns a boolean (or status object) indicating if the system is under maintenance, allowing developers to disable trading features gracefully.
notes: Essential for UX; prevents users from placing orders that will fail during scheduled maintenance windows.
Can be used to disable specific actions (like deposits) while allowing read-only data (like market history) if the API permits.
Combine with a polling interval or refresh mechanism if the app stays open for long periods.

patterns.name: useOdosQuote
patterns.description: Hook for useOdosQuote
patterns.usage: Fetches a swap quote using the Odos aggregator integration. This allows you to get the best price execution path for token swaps within the Orderly ecosystem.
notes: Used for pre-transaction estimation; does not execute the swap itself.
Returns detailed routing information, including output amount and gas estimates.
Essential for building a 'Swap' interface UI.

patterns.name: useOpenInterest
patterns.description: Hook for useOpenInterest
patterns.usage: Fetches Open Interest data for a specific market. Open Interest represents the total number of outstanding derivative contracts (longs + shorts) that are held by market participants.
notes: Often returns an array of historical data points for charting.
A key indicator of market liquidity and sentiment.
Data is usually aggregated over time intervals (e.g., hourly or daily).

patterns.name: useSettleSubscription
patterns.description: Hook for useSettleSubscription
patterns.usage: Subscribes to settlement events from the exchange. This is crucial for tracking when positions are settled, funding fees are charged/credited, or PnL is realized.
notes: Settlement events directly impact the user's available balance and position value.
This hook ensures the UI reflects these changes immediately without requiring a page refresh.
Essential for accurate accounting in perpetual futures trading.

patterns.name: useStorageLedgerAddress
patterns.description: Hook for useStorageLedgerAddress
patterns.usage: Retrieves the Orderly Ledger Address associated with the current session from storage. This is the specific address used for trading on the Orderly network, which may differ from the user's wallet address.
notes: Useful for debugging connection issues or displaying the specific trading account ID.
Reads from persistent storage, so it can survive page refreshes.
Returns null or undefined if the user has not yet connected/registered a wallet.

patterns.name: useTokensInfo
patterns.description: Hook for useTokensInfo
patterns.usage: Retrieves a list of all supported tokens with their metadata, such as display precision (decimals), token logos, and which blockchain networks they support.
notes: Essential for rendering deposit/withdraw forms where the user needs to select a specific network (e.g., Arbitrum vs Optimism).
The `decimals` field here is crucial for formatting user balances correctly in the UI.
Data is usually fetched once and cached, as it doesn't change often.

patterns.name: useTokenInfo
patterns.description: Hook for useTokenInfo
patterns.usage: A focused hook to retrieve metadata for a single token. Useful when displaying details for a specific asset without loading the entire token list.
notes: More efficient than `useTokensInfo` if you only need data for one specific asset.
Returns `null` or `undefined` if the token symbol is not supported by Orderly.
Use this to dynamically determine decimal places for input fields based on the selected asset.

patterns.name: useTransfer
patterns.description: Hook for useTransfer
patterns.usage: Handles the movement of funds between the user's Wallet Account (off-chain/chain balance) and their Trading Account (collateral account) on the Orderly Network.
notes: Ensure you check the user's available balance before initiating a transfer to prevent UI errors.
The `type` parameter determines the direction: `WALLET_TO_TRADING` adds margin, `TRADING_TO_WALLET` removes it.
Transfers usually require a signature from the connected wallet.

patterns.name: useBalanceTopic
patterns.description: Hook for useBalanceTopic
patterns.usage: A utility hook that returns the specific topic string required to subscribe to balance updates via the Orderly Network WebSocket API. Useful for custom WebSocket integrations.
notes: This is typically used internally by higher-level hooks like `useWalletSubscription`, but is exposed for advanced usage.
The topic string usually follows a format like `balance` or includes account identifiers.
Useful if you are building a custom data fetching layer and need to know exactly which channel to subscribe to.

patterns.name: useFundingRateBySymbol
patterns.description: Hook for useFundingRateBySymbol
patterns.usage: Fetches the funding rate data for a specific trading symbol. This is vital for perpetual futures traders to understand the cost of holding positions.
notes: Funding rates are typically returned as decimals (e.g., 0.0001), so you must multiply by 100 to display as a percentage.
The 'predicted' rate helps traders anticipate future costs, while the current rate is used for settlement.
Display the nextFundingTime to inform users when the next fee/reward will be applied to their position.

patterns.name: useIndexPrice
patterns.description: Hook for useIndexPrice
patterns.usage: Retrieves the Index Price for a specific trading pair. The Index Price is the fair value of the underlying asset, usually derived from an average of spot prices on various exchanges, used to calculate mark prices.
notes: Crucial for derivatives trading to understand the fair value of the contract distinct from the last traded price.
Returns a single value (number or string) representing the price at the time of the fetch or update.
Use this to display the 'Oracle' price to users, helping them understand funding rate calculations.

patterns.name: useIndexPricesStream
patterns.description: Hook for useIndexPricesStream
patterns.usage: Streams index prices for multiple symbols simultaneously. It returns a dataset of all prices and a helper function `getIndexPrice` to efficiently query a specific symbol's price from the stream.
notes: More efficient than calling `useIndexPrice` multiple times if you need prices for several pairs on one screen.
The `getIndexPrice` helper allows for quick lookups without manually iterating through the `data` object.
Data updates automatically via WebSocket, providing a live ticker tape experience.

patterns.name: useLeverageBySymbol
patterns.description: Hook for useLeverageBySymbol
patterns.usage: A lightweight hook specifically for retrieving the current leverage setting for a given symbol. Unlike `useLeverage`, it is read-only and does not provide update functions.
notes: Ideal for display components (like tables or headers) where you need to show leverage but don't need controls to change it.
Returns `undefined` or `null` if the symbol is invalid or data hasn't loaded yet.
Useful for calculating margin requirements or liquidation prices in read-only views.

patterns.name: useMarkPrice
patterns.description: Hook for useMarkPrice
patterns.usage: Retrieves the Mark Price for a specific symbol. The Mark Price is used to determine the unrealized PnL and liquidation threshold of positions, distinct from the Index Price and Last Traded Price.
notes: Mark Price is typically calculated as a weighted average of the Index Price and moving average of the Mid-Price to prevent manipulation.
This is the price you should use when calculating user equity and margin ratio for liquidation warnings.
Updates frequently; ensure your display components handle rapid number changes gracefully.

patterns.name: useMarkPricesStream
patterns.description: Hook for useMarkPricesStream
patterns.usage: Streams Mark Prices for all available trading pairs. This is the most efficient way to monitor the fair value of multiple positions simultaneously for real-time PnL calculation.
notes: Crucial for building a real-time 'Portfolio' or 'Positions' tab where values change every second.
Returns an object/map keyed by symbol, allowing O(1) lookup time.
Since this is a stream, ensure your component is optimized to handle re-renders, or memoize the calculated values.

patterns.name: useMarketList
patterns.description: Hook for useMarketList
patterns.usage: Fetches the comprehensive list of supported markets (trading pairs). This includes metadata such as symbol, display name, minimum order size, tick size, and market type (Spot/Perp).
notes: This is the primary source of truth for populating dropdowns and market selectors in your app.
Contains vital validation data like `min_order_qty` and `tick_size` which must be used in order forms to prevent API rejections.
The data is relatively static, so it's often cached or fetched once on app mount.

patterns.name: useMarketMap
patterns.description: Hook for useMarketMap
patterns.usage: Retrieves the global map of all available markets from the Orderly store. This is useful for populating dropdown selectors, displaying asset lists, or looking up static market metadata like tick size or step size without making individual API calls.
notes: Returns a key-value object where keys are symbols (e.g., 'PERP_ETH_USDC') and values are market info objects.
Data is usually cached in the Zustand store, making access synchronous and extremely fast.
Use this to derive lists of symbols for UI selectors rather than hardcoding them.

patterns.name: useMarket
patterns.description: Hook for useMarket
patterns.usage: Fetches detailed static and semi-static data for a specific trading pair. It returns metadata such as decimal places (`quote_dp`), creation timestamp, and current open interest figures.
notes: Requires a `symbol` string (e.g., 'PERP_BTC_USDC') as an argument.
Useful for determining precision (dp) for formatting price inputs or displays.
Combines static config data with some dynamic data like Open Interest.

patterns.name: useMarketsStore
patterns.description: Hook for useMarketsStore
patterns.usage: Provides access to the global markets state store, specifically for interacting with user preferences like favorited markets. It exposes actions to modify the state (e.g., `updateFavorites`).
notes: This is a state management hook (Zustand), not a data fetching hook.
Allows you to persist user preferences (like favorite trading pairs) locally.
Changes made here reflect immediately across all components consuming the store.

patterns.name: useMarketsStream
patterns.description: Hook for useMarketsStream
patterns.usage: Subscribes to the public ticker stream for all supported markets. It returns real-time data including the last price, 24h volume, and 24h price change for every market.
notes: Provides a bulk update of market data, ideal for a 'Market Overview' or 'All Markets' page.
Data updates frequently via WebSocket; ensure your UI handles re-renders efficiently.
The `data` array contains objects keyed by market symbol.

patterns.name: useRwaSymbolsInfo
patterns.description: Hook for useRwaSymbolsInfo
patterns.usage: Retrieves metadata for Real World Asset (RWA) symbols, specifically focusing on trading hours. It determines if the market is currently open and when the next session begins or ends.
notes: Essential for RWA markets (e.g., US Stocks) which do not trade 24/7 like crypto.
Helps prevent order placement errors by checking the 'open' boolean before allowing trades.
Returns ISO timestamps for scheduling purposes.

patterns.name: useRwaSymbolsInfoStore
patterns.description: Hook for useRwaSymbolsInfoStore
patterns.usage: Provides direct access to the RWA symbols info state store. This is useful for accessing cached market hours data without triggering re-fetches or for accessing the state globally across the application.
notes: Reads from the global state (likely Zustand) initialized by other hooks.
More performant than `useRwaSymbolsInfo` if you just need to read data without side effects.
Ensure `useInitRwaSymbolsRuntime` has been called to populate this store.

patterns.name: useInitRwaSymbolsRuntime
patterns.description: Hook for useInitRwaSymbolsRuntime
patterns.usage: An initialization hook that fetches and sets up the runtime data for RWA (Real World Asset) symbols. It ensures that trading hours and market status information are available globally for the application.
notes: Should be called once at the root level of the application (e.g., in App.tsx or a custom Provider).
It populates the store used by `useRwaSymbolsInfoStore`.
Necessary for any RWA-related logic to function correctly within the SDK.

patterns.name: useSymbolInfo
patterns.description: Hook for useSymbolInfo
patterns.usage: Retrieves detailed metadata for a specific trading symbol. This includes trading rules like minimum order size, tick size (price precision), and maximum leverage.
notes: Critical for form validation (e.g., ensuring user input respects min_order_size and tick_size).
Data is often fetched once and cached, but should be checked before allowing order submission.
Helps in dynamically configuring input fields (step amounts) based on the symbol.

patterns.name: useSymbolLeverage
patterns.description: Hook for useSymbolLeverage
patterns.usage: Fetches the current leverage setting for a specific trading symbol and allows you to update it. It handles the API interaction to modify margin requirements.
notes: Always check the `maxLeverage` returned by the hook before allowing user input to prevent API errors.
The `updateLeverage` function is asynchronous; ensure you handle loading states to prevent double-submissions.
Changing leverage may affect your existing position's liquidation price immediately.

patterns.name: useSymbolsInfo
patterns.description: Hook for useSymbolsInfo
patterns.usage: Retrieves static information for all trading symbols, such as tick size, lot size, minimum order size, and asset pairs. Essential for building order forms and market lists.
notes: This data is relatively static but should be fetched on app mount to ensure trading rules are up to date.
Use the `min_order_qty` and `tick_size` fields from this data to validate user order inputs before submission.
The return type is usually an array of objects containing detailed symbol configurations.

patterns.name: useSymbolsInfoStore
patterns.description: Hook for useSymbolsInfoStore
patterns.usage: Provides direct access to the Zustand store managing symbol information. This is ideal for performance optimization, avoiding redundant network requests when multiple components need symbol data.
notes: This relies on the store being populated, usually by a parent component using `useSymbolsInfo` or a provider.
Use selectors (e.g., `state => state.symbols`) to prevent unnecessary re-renders of components.
It provides helper functions like `getSymbol(id)` for quick lookups.

patterns.name: useWSObserver
patterns.description: Hook for useWSObserver
patterns.usage: Monitors the health and state of the Orderly Network WebSocket connection. It is useful for displaying real-time connection status to the user or debugging connectivity issues.
notes: This is an internal hook primarily used to track the lifecycle of the socket (connecting, open, closed).
It does not return message data; use specific subscription hooks (like useBalanceSubscription) for data.
Status changes are reactive, allowing UI components to update instantly when connection drops or recovers.

patterns.name: useHoldingStream
patterns.description: Hook for useHoldingStream
patterns.usage: Streams the user's account holdings (balances) and frozen assets (locked in open orders) in real-time. This is essential for displaying up-to-date wallet information without manual refreshing.
notes: Provides real-time updates via WebSocket, ensuring the UI reflects balance changes immediately after fills or deposits.
The 'frozen' return value represents funds locked in open orders; subtract this from 'holding' to get available balance.
Handles connection lifecycle automatically, but you should still check if the data exists before rendering.

patterns.name: usePrivateDataObserver
patterns.description: Hook for usePrivateDataObserver
patterns.usage: A generic observer for private user data streams. It is often used to watch for specific data types like order history, trade history, or liquidation events, returning structured rows for tabular display.
notes: This hook is highly efficient for rendering lists (tables) of user activity.
It abstracts the websocket connection logic, providing direct access to data arrays.
Ensure you handle loading states or empty arrays before rendering to avoid UI errors.

patterns.name: usePublicDataObserver
patterns.description: Hook for usePublicDataObserver
patterns.usage: A generic hook for observing public market data streams via websocket. It can be configured to watch for trades, tickers, or candle updates depending on the implementation parameters.
notes: Provides real-time updates without the need for HTTP polling.
Useful for building components like 'Recent Trades', 'Market Tickers', or 'Price Tickers'.
Data structure depends on the specific topic (e.g., 'TRADE' vs 'TICKER') requested.

patterns.name: useTickerStream
patterns.description: Hook for useTickerStream
patterns.usage: Establishes a WebSocket connection to receive real-time market data updates, including last price, 24h volume, and price change percentages for all or specific symbols.
notes: This hook manages the WebSocket lifecycle automatically (connecting and disconnecting based on component mount).
Data updates frequently; ensure your UI rendering is optimized to handle rapid prop changes.
Use this for displaying live market overviews rather than single-order execution data.

patterns.name: useWS
patterns.description: Hook for useWS
patterns.usage: Manages the WebSocket connection to the Orderly Network for real-time data. It provides methods to subscribe to topics, send messages, and listen for incoming data streams.
notes: Essential for building high-frequency trading interfaces or real-time charting.
Always clean up subscriptions (using `off`) in the useEffect cleanup to prevent memory leaks.
Handles the connection lifecycle (connect/disconnect/reconnect) internally.

patterns.name: useWsStatus
patterns.description: Hook for useWsStatus
patterns.usage: Monitors and returns the real-time status of the WebSocket connection. This is vital for providing feedback to users about whether they are receiving live market data.
notes: Status typically includes 'connected', 'connecting', 'disconnected', and 'error'.
Use this to trigger UI alerts or toasts when the connection is lost.
Helps users distinguish between a frozen market and a connection issue.

patterns.name: useAssetsHistory
patterns.description: Hook for useAssetsHistory
patterns.usage: Retrieves the historical value of the user's assets or portfolio equity. This is essential for rendering PnL charts or account growth over time.
notes: Returns an array of historical data points, usually containing timestamps and equity values.
Useful for visualizing trading performance or account balance trends.
May require the user to be authenticated (wallet connected) to fetch specific account data.

patterns.name: useDistributionHistory
patterns.description: Hook for useDistributionHistory
patterns.usage: Fetches the history of reward distributions (e.g., trading fee rebates or staking rewards) paid to the user. It often includes summary metrics like the current annual rate.
notes: The return value includes `annual_rate`, which represents the estimated yield based on recent distributions.
Data is useful for calculating ROI on staked or provided liquidity.
Ensure the user has connected their wallet to view personal distribution history.

patterns.name: useFundingFeeHistory
patterns.description: Hook for useFundingFeeHistory
patterns.usage: Retrieves the history of funding fees for perpetual trading positions. This helps users track the cost or profit derived from the funding rate mechanism over time.
notes: Returns `annual_rate` which can be used to project future costs/revenues.
Distinguish between positive (received) and negative (paid) amounts in the UI.
Critical for perps traders to understand the 'carry cost' of their positions.

patterns.name: useTransferHistory
patterns.description: Hook for useTransferHistory
patterns.usage: Retrieves a log of funds moving in and out of the account (deposits and withdrawals). This is essential for the 'Wallet' or 'Assets' section of an application.
notes: Returns an array of transfer objects containing status, amount, token, and timestamp.
Use this to track the state of pending deposits or withdrawals.
Combine with `useChainInfo` to generate transaction explorer links for on-chain transfers.

patterns.name: useFundingRateHistory
patterns.description: Hook for useFundingRateHistory
patterns.usage: Retrieves a historical log of funding rates for a specific market. Useful for displaying charts or tables of past funding payments.
notes: Returns an array of data points containing timestamps and rates.
Includes an `isLoading` state to handle async data fetching gracefully.
Ideal for integration with charting libraries like Recharts or Chart.js.

patterns.name: useVaultsHistory
patterns.description: Hook for useVaultsHistory
patterns.usage: Accesses historical data for liquidity vaults or strategy vaults. This shows user interactions with specific vault products over time.
notes: Useful for displaying a user's investment journey in specific Orderly vaults.
Can include data on yield farming performance or liquidity provision history.
Ensure the UI handles cases where the user has not interacted with any vaults.

patterns.name: useDeposit
patterns.description: Hook for useDeposit
patterns.usage: Retrieves the specific deposit address and metadata required to fund a trading account with a specific token on a specific chain.
notes: Returns the smart contract or wallet address where funds should be sent.
Includes `decimals` to ensure the UI displays amounts correctly.
Crucial for preventing user error (sending tokens to the wrong chain).

patterns.name: useMaxWithdrawal
patterns.description: Hook for useMaxWithdrawal
patterns.usage: Calculates and retrieves the maximum amount of a specific token that can be withdrawn from the account, taking into account account balance, margin requirements, and pending orders.
notes: Requires the user to be authenticated/wallet connected.
The value changes dynamically based on open positions and order collateral.
Useful for validating user input in withdrawal forms to prevent API errors.

patterns.name: useWithdraw
patterns.description: Hook for useWithdraw
patterns.usage: Manages the withdrawal of funds from the Orderly Network to an external blockchain address. It returns specific token and chain metadata required to format the transaction.
notes: The hook returns `decimals` specifically so you can format the input field precision correctly for the selected token.
Withdrawals involve on-chain transactions and may take time depending on the network congestion.
Ensure the user has sufficient balance in their *Trading Account* (and has transferred to Wallet if necessary) before withdrawing.

patterns.name: useLeverage
patterns.description: Hook for useLeverage
patterns.usage: Manages the leverage setting for a specific trading symbol. It provides the current leverage, maximum allowed leverage, predefined leverage steps (levers), and a function to update the leverage.
notes: Changing leverage often requires it to apply to future positions only, or it might affect existing position margin depending on the broker's configuration.
`leverageLevers` typically provides an array of safe leverage increments (e.g., [1, 2, 5, 10, 20]) to use in UI dropdowns.
Always respect `maxLeverage` in your UI validation to prevent API errors.

patterns.name: useReferralRebateSummary
patterns.description: Hook for useReferralRebateSummary
patterns.usage: Provides a financial summary of the rewards earned through the referral program, distinguishing between claimed (total) and pending amounts.
notes: Crucial for displaying the user's earnings from their referral activity.
Data is typically aggregated over time (e.g., lifetime earnings).
Ensure you handle cases where rebate data might be undefined or zero.

patterns.name: useMediaQuery
patterns.description: Hook for useMediaQuery
patterns.usage: A responsive design hook that returns a boolean indicating whether the current viewport matches the provided CSS media query string.
notes: Useful for toggling UI components like sidebars, tabs, or changing table layouts.
Relies on window.matchMedia and updates automatically on resize.
Prefer this over CSS-only solutions when you need to conditionally render entire React components.

patterns.name: CheckboxIcon
patterns.description: A visual icon component representing a checked state. It is typically used inside custom checkbox containers or buttons to indicate selection.
patterns.usage: Use this icon when building custom form controls or toggle buttons where you need to visually represent a 'checked' boolean state. It is often paired with a container div that handles the background color.
notes: The icon itself does not handle state (checked/unchecked); it is purely visual.
Commonly styled with utility classes like `oui-text-primary` or `oui-text-white` depending on the background contrast.

patterns.name: EmptyStateIcon
patterns.description: A graphical placeholder icon used to indicate that a list, table, or section has no data to display.
patterns.usage: Render this component inside tables, lists, or card containers when the data array is empty or when a search yields no results.
notes: This is a static SVG component.
Often wrapped in a container with reduced opacity to soften the visual impact.

patterns.name: InputPrefix
patterns.description: A wrapper component used to display content (like currency symbols or icons) immediately before the input text cursor.
patterns.usage: Use this to prepend fixed text or icons to an input field, such as a currency symbol ($), a network identifier, or a search icon.
notes: The `prefix` prop accepts a React Node (string, number, JSX element).
Ensure the `id` passed to InputPrefix matches the `id` of the input element for accessibility.

patterns.name: InputSuffix
patterns.description: A wrapper component used to display content (like units, currency codes, or action buttons) immediately after the input text.
patterns.usage: Use this to append fixed text or icons to an input field, such as a currency ticker (USDT), a percentage sign (%), or a clear button.
notes: The `suffix` prop accepts a React Node.
Useful for maintaining alignment of input text while keeping labels fixed to the right.

patterns.name: TextField
patterns.description: A standard text input wrapper that includes label, placeholder, and error handling styling. It supports controlled component patterns.
patterns.usage: Use for form inputs requiring user text entry, such as referral codes, account names, or search queries.
notes: The `fullWidth` prop makes the input take 100% width of its parent container.
It functions as a controlled input; ensure you manage `value` and `onChange` state.

patterns.name: ExtensionProvider
patterns.description: A Context Provider that enables the plugin/extension system within the application tree. It makes registered extensions available to `ExtensionSlot` components.
patterns.usage: Wrap your application root or a specific layout section with this provider to allow dynamic injection of UI components via the extension system.
notes: Must be placed higher in the component tree than any `ExtensionSlot` that intends to use its extensions.
Accepts an array of extension objects containing configuration and render logic.

patterns.name: ExtensionSlot
patterns.description: A placeholder component that renders specific UI extensions based on the `position` prop. It acts as a mount point for dynamic content.
patterns.usage: Place this component in layouts where you want third-party plugins or internal modules to inject UI elements (e.g., adding a button to the mobile menu or a custom empty state).
notes: Requires an `ExtensionProvider` to be ancestor in the tree.
Uses `ExtensionPositionEnum` to define standard locations (like `MobileAccountMenu` or `EmptyDataIdentifier`).

patterns.name: CombineSelect
patterns.description: A compact select dropdown component that combines a trigger button with a selection menu. It supports various sizes and option configurations.
patterns.usage: Ideal for selecting order types (Limit/Market), timeframes, or other discrete settings where space is limited (e.g., trading headers or toolbars).
notes: The `size` prop accepts values like 'xs' for compact layouts.
Uses `onValueChange` for handling updates rather than standard DOM events.
Accepts `options` prop which is an array of objects with label and value.

patterns.name: TokenSelect
patterns.description: A dropdown component specifically designed for selecting cryptocurrency tokens. It typically handles token display, including icons and symbols, and manages the selection state.
patterns.usage: Use in trading forms or asset transfer modals where the user needs to specify which token they are interacting with.
notes: Ensure the tokens array includes 'symbol' and 'logo' properties for proper rendering.
The 'onSelect' callback returns the full token object or symbol depending on implementation.

patterns.name: SliderTip
patterns.description: A visual indicator (tooltip) that displays the current value of a slider interaction. It is often used to overlay the value on top of a slider track or thumb.
patterns.usage: Integrate with range sliders to provide real-time feedback on the percentage or absolute value selected by the user.
notes: Requires a 'value' prop to determine what text to display.
The 'max' prop helps calculate percentage positioning if the component handles internal positioning.

patterns.name: DataFilter
patterns.description: A component used to filter datasets, often appearing as a segmented control or a tab group above tables or lists.
patterns.usage: Place above a `DataTable` or list view to allow users to toggle between different data states (e.g., Open Orders vs. History).
notes: The 'items' prop expects an array of objects with 'label' and 'value'.
It supports custom className for styling overrides, specifically useful for removing borders or padding.

patterns.name: DataTable
patterns.description: A comprehensive table component for displaying structured data. It handles loading states, empty states, and custom styling via class names.
patterns.usage: The primary component for displaying order history, trade history, or position data in a trading interface.
notes: Use 'dataSource' to pass the array of data objects.
'classNames' prop allows deep styling customization for root, header, body, etc.
Provide an 'emptyView' component to handle cases with no data.

patterns.name: TableBody
patterns.description: The container component for the rows of a table. It renders the `<tbody>` and handles the iteration over row data.
patterns.usage: Used when constructing a custom table layout or when extending the default `DataTable` with specific row rendering logic.
notes: The 'rows' prop typically contains the data structure to be iterated over.
The 'bordered' prop toggles borders between rows/cells.

patterns.name: TableCell
patterns.description: A component responsible for rendering a single cell within a table row. It handles alignment and basic formatting based on the cell data.
patterns.usage: Used inside `TableBody` or `DataTable` to standardize how individual data points are displayed.
notes: The 'cell' prop usually contains the raw value and metadata (like alignment).
Supports className overrides for specific cell styling.

patterns.name: NumTypeRoi
patterns.description: A typography component specifically for formatting Return on Investment (ROI) figures. It automatically applies color coding (green for positive, red for negative).
patterns.usage: Ideal for portfolio summaries, strategy performance cards, or history tables displaying percentage gains/losses.
notes: Automatically handles color based on the sign of the value.
Accepts a 'suffix' prop (e.g., '%') to append units.

patterns.name: NumTypePnl
patterns.description: A typography component for formatting Profit and Loss (PnL) values. It ensures consistent decimal formatting and color indication for financial data.
patterns.usage: Used in position rows, account balances, and trade history to clearly show profit or loss amounts.
notes: Use 'decimals' to control precision.
Colors typically default to green for positive and red for negative values.

patterns.name: NumTypeNotional
patterns.description: A typography component specifically designed to display the notional value of trading positions. It handles decimal formatting appropriate for contract sizes and total position values.
patterns.usage: Use in position tables, portfolio summaries, or trade confirmations where the total dollar value of a position needs to be displayed clearly.
notes: Automatically formats large numbers with commas or abbreviations depending on the internal configuration.
Typically inherits color themes from the parent theme (e.g., red/green for PnL contexts if applicable).

patterns.name: NumTypeAssetValue
patterns.description: A typography component for displaying the value of a specific asset. It ensures consistent decimal precision and symbol placement across the application.
patterns.usage: Ideal for displaying wallet balances, asset allocation breakdowns, or individual coin holdings.
notes: Use the `symbol` prop to append currency tickers (e.g., USD, ETH).
Handles precision scaling automatically based on the asset type if not explicitly overridden.

patterns.name: NumTypeCollateral
patterns.description: A specialized typography component for displaying collateral values. It formats numbers specifically for margin requirements and account health metrics.
patterns.usage: Use in the account overview bar, margin calculator, or liquidation risk panels.
notes: Ensures high precision is maintained where required for margin calculations.
Often used in conjunction with health bars or risk meters.

patterns.name: AuthGuard
patterns.description: A conditional wrapper that checks authentication status. If the user is not connected or does not have an Orderly account, it renders a call-to-action button to trigger the connection flow. Otherwise, it renders the children components.
patterns.usage: Wrap critical trading actions (Place Order, Withdraw, Create API Key) to ensure only authenticated users can interact with them.
notes: Accepts `buttonProps` to customize the appearance of the 'Connect' button that appears when unauthenticated.
Requires `OrderlyContext` to be available in the component tree.

patterns.name: AuthGuardEmpty
patterns.description: A silent authentication guard. It renders its children only if the user is authenticated. If the user is not authenticated, it renders nothing (null), effectively hiding the protected UI elements without prompting.
patterns.usage: Use for dashboard sections, private navigation links, or data tables that should simply disappear for guest users rather than showing a login prompt.
notes: Does not render any UI feedback for unauthenticated users.
Useful for 'clean' UI layouts where you don't want empty placeholders or login buttons cluttering the view.

patterns.name: WalletConnectorWidget
patterns.description: A standalone, all-in-one component that handles the wallet connection UI. It displays a 'Connect Wallet' button when disconnected, and manages the account dropdown/modal when connected.
patterns.usage: Place in the application header (navbar) as the primary entry point for wallet connection and account management.
notes: Handles the connection flow logic internally via the Orderly Connector context.
Usually supports switching networks and disconnecting within its dropdown menu.

patterns.name: LeverageInput
patterns.description: An input component specifically designed for entering leverage values. It handles validation (min/max limits) and ensures the input is treated as a numerical multiplier.
patterns.usage: Use in trading settings panels or order forms where users need to manually type or fine-tune their leverage multiplier.
notes: Often includes visual indicators for max leverage limits.
Prevents invalid inputs (like negative numbers or text).

patterns.name: LeverageSelector
patterns.description: A UI component for selecting leverage, typically featuring a slider or preset buttons. It offers a more visual and constrained way to adjust leverage compared to a text input.
patterns.usage: Best for user-friendly trading interfaces where users want to quickly slide or click to set common leverage levels (1x, 10x, 20x, etc.).
notes: The `marks` prop allows you to define specific leverage steps available to the user.
Provides immediate visual feedback on the risk level associated with the leverage.

patterns.name: LTVRiskTooltipUI
patterns.description: A tooltip component designed to display Loan-to-Value (LTV) risk information. It helps users understand their margin usage and liquidation risk at a glance.
patterns.usage: Use this in account summary sections or order entry forms where users need to be aware of their leverage risk relative to their collateral.
notes: Typically appears as an icon (info/warning) that expands on hover.
Ensure the `ltv` prop is a decimal (e.g., 0.5 for 50%).

patterns.name: AdditionalConfigButton
patterns.description: A toggle button component used to reveal or hide advanced configuration options within the order entry interface, such as Take Profit/Stop Loss settings or Post-Only modes.
patterns.usage: Place this below the main price/quantity inputs to keep the UI clean while allowing power users to access advanced order types.
notes: The `active` prop usually changes the visual style (e.g., background color) to indicate the panel is open.
It accepts children to customize the button label.

patterns.name: AdvancedTPSLResult
patterns.description: Displays the calculated result of an order that includes Advanced Take Profit (TP) and Stop Loss (SL) parameters. It validates and shows the trigger prices and expected outcomes.
patterns.usage: Render this inside the order confirmation modal or the advanced settings panel to show the user exactly what their TP/SL settings will execute at.
notes: Requires `symbolInfo` to format prices correctly according to the market's precision.
Passing an `errors` object with keys will display validation messages inline.

patterns.name: AssetInfo
patterns.description: Displays critical information about the trading asset, including the quote currency, estimated liquidation price, and current mark price. It also indicates if the asset is tradeable.
patterns.usage: Ideal for the header of the order entry box or the account overview section to give users context on their position's health.
notes: If `canTrade` is false, the component might visually disable itself or show a warning.
Liquidation price is a key metric for risk management.

patterns.name: EffectiveFeeUI
patterns.description: A presentational component that renders the effective fee rate (after volume discounts or token rebates) for either Maker or Taker orders.
patterns.usage: Use this in fee breakdown sections or tooltips where you need to show the specific rate the user is currently paying.
notes: The `value` prop is typically a decimal number (e.g., 0.001 for 0.1%).
It usually handles formatting (percentage display) internally.

patterns.name: EffectiveFeesWidget
patterns.description: A composite widget that displays both Maker and Taker effective fees. It is designed to show the user's actual trading costs based on their current tier.
patterns.usage: Place this in the order entry footer or account settings to inform users of their discounted fee rates.
notes: Handles negative values (rebates) gracefully, often displaying them in green.
Requires both `maker` and `taker` props to render fully.

patterns.name: FeesWidget
patterns.description: A widget that fetches and displays fee information for a specific trading symbol. It abstracts the logic of looking up fee tiers for the given market.
patterns.usage: Useful when you want to display standard fee rates for a specific market without manually calculating effective rates.
notes: It likely fetches data from the Orderly SDK context or API based on the `symbol` prop.
Ensure the symbol string matches the Orderly format (e.g., PERP_ETH_USDC).

patterns.name: RegularFeesUI
patterns.description: Displays the standard (base) fee rates before any discounts or rebates are applied. This serves as a reference point for users to see their savings.
patterns.usage: Best used in comparison views or tooltips showing 'Standard Rate' vs 'Your Rate'.
notes: Unlike `EffectiveFeesWidget`, this is purely presentational and expects raw number props.
Helpful in pricing pages or FAQ sections regarding fees.

patterns.name: RegularFeesWidget
patterns.description: A display component that renders the Maker and Taker fee rates for a specific market or asset class. It is often used in the footer or header of an order entry form to inform users of trading costs before execution.
patterns.usage:
Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-order-entry

Use this component when you need to display fee statictics. It accepts string or number props for `taker` and `maker` fees.
notes: taker (string | number): The fee rate for taker orders (e.g., '0.05').
maker (string | number): The fee rate for maker orders (e.g., '0.02').

patterns.name: OrderEntryHeader
patterns.description: The top navigation bar for the Order Entry interface. It displays the trading pair symbol, allows switching between Buy/Sell sides, and indicates the current order type (Limit/Market).
patterns.usage:
Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-order-entry

Place this at the top of your custom order form. It handles the visual state of the trading direction.
notes: symbol (string): The trading pair symbol (e.g., 'PERP_ETH_USDC').
canTrade (boolean): Disables interaction if trading is halted for the symbol.
side ('buy' | 'sell'): The current selected side.
order_type ('limit' | 'market'): The current selected order type.

patterns.name: OrderInput
patterns.description: A compound input component handling Price and Amount entry. It manages formatting, decimal precision based on the symbol's tick size, and layout constraints.
patterns.usage:
Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-order-entry

This is a controlled component. Pass the current form state via `values` and update it via `onValuesChange`.
notes: values (object): Contains { price: string, amount: string }.
onValuesChange (function): Callback when inputs change.
priceInputContainerWidth (string): CSS width for the price input container.

patterns.name: PnlInputProvider
patterns.description: A provider component that wraps the logic and UI for Stop Loss (SL) or Take Profit (TP) inputs. It calculates the trigger price and size based on the parent order context.
patterns.usage:
Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-order-entry

Wrap this around your advanced order settings. The `type` prop determines if it renders Stop Loss or Take Profit fields.
notes: values (object): The current state of the TP/SL configuration.
type ('SL' | 'TP'): Specifies if this is a Stop Loss or Take Profit input.
onValuesChange (function): Handler for updating TP/SL state.

patterns.name: ReduceOnlySwitch
patterns.description: A toggle switch component specifically for the 'Reduce Only' order flag. When enabled, the order will only close existing positions and not open new ones.
patterns.usage:
Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-order-entry

Use this in the order configuration section. It is a controlled boolean component.
notes: checked (boolean): Whether the switch is active.
onCheckedChange (function): Callback returning the new boolean state.

patterns.name: OrderEntry
patterns.description: The main container component for the order entry interface. It aggregates the header, inputs, buttons, and fee widgets into a cohesive unit. It handles the business logic for order creation.
patterns.usage:
Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-order-entry

Use this if you need the full order entry functionality but perhaps want to wrap it in a custom layout or container.
notes: symbol (string): The trading pair symbol.
disableFeatures (object): Object to hide specific features like 'reduceOnly' or 'postOnly'.
containerRef (RefObject): Reference to the container DOM element.

patterns.name: OrderEntryWidget
patterns.description: A high-level, plug-and-play widget that encapsulates the entire Order Entry experience. It includes the header, price/size inputs, order type selection, and submission buttons.
patterns.usage:
Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-order-entry

This is the easiest way to add trading functionality to your app. Simply pass the symbol and a container ref.
notes: symbol (string): Required symbol for the trading pair.
containerRef (RefObject): Required ref to the parent div for portal/modal positioning.
disableFeatures (object): Allows granular control over which order features are available.

patterns.name: MobileOrderListWidget
patterns.description: A responsive widget designed specifically for mobile screens to display a list of open, filled, or historical orders. It supports filtering by symbol.
patterns.usage:
Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-orders

Ideal for mobile-first trading interfaces. Pass `undefined` to the symbol prop to show a global order list across all markets.
notes: symbol (string | undefined): The specific symbol to filter orders. Pass undefined for all symbols.
onSymbolChange (function): Callback when the user changes the symbol filter.

patterns.name: Orders
patterns.description: A comprehensive table component for displaying user orders. It supports different states (open, filled, history) and handles the display of order details like price, size, and status.
patterns.usage: Use this component to render the main order management interface in your trading dashboard. It automatically fetches data based on the provided props.
notes: Ensure the app is wrapped in OrderlyProvider.
Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-orders

patterns.name: ShareButtonWidget
patterns.description: A button widget that triggers a modal allowing users to share their Profit and Loss (PnL) or specific trade details, often for social sharing or community engagement.
patterns.usage: Place this button next to specific order or position rows in a table to allow users to share their performance.
notes: Can accept either an 'order' or 'position' prop.
Requires a 'sharePnLConfig' object to customize the shareable content.

patterns.name: CloseAllPositionsWidget
patterns.description: A widget (typically a button or small control panel) that allows users to liquidate all open positions for a specific symbol or for the entire account.
patterns.usage: Useful in risk management sections or at the top of a positions table to allow users to exit markets quickly.
notes: Install: npm install @orderly.network/ui-positions
Passing 'undefined' or omitting the symbol prop usually implies closing all positions globally.

patterns.name: LiquidationWidget
patterns.description: A data table component displaying historical liquidation events. It shows details such as the time of liquidation, price, and size.
patterns.usage: Implement in the 'History' or 'Reports' tab of your application to show users past liquidation events.
notes: If the 'symbol' prop is undefined, it typically shows liquidations for all symbols.

patterns.name: MobileLiquidationWidget
patterns.description: A mobile-optimized version of the LiquidationWidget. It presents liquidation records in a card or list format suitable for smaller screens rather than a wide table.
patterns.usage: Use this within your mobile-specific layout routes or responsive breakpoints where the desktop table would not fit.
notes: Supports custom class names for styling cells and rows to match mobile themes.
Includes built-in load more functionality via 'enableLoadMore'.

patterns.name: PositionHistoryWidget
patterns.description: Displays a table of closed positions. It calculates and shows the realized PnL for positions that have been exited.
patterns.usage: Essential for the 'History' section, allowing users to review their past trading performance on specific assets.
notes: Use 'pnlNotionalDecimalPrecision' to control how many decimal places are shown for PnL values.

patterns.name: MobilePositionHistoryWidget
patterns.description: A mobile-friendly card list view of closed position history. It allows users to browse their past trades on mobile devices.
patterns.usage: Deploy this in your mobile trading interface to replace the standard desktop history table.
notes: Provides an 'onSymbolChange' callback to handle filtering logic when a user selects a specific symbol from the history.

patterns.name: NumeralWithCtx
patterns.description: A utility component to format numerical values. It automatically determines decimal precision based on the current trading symbol's context (defined in OrderlyConfig).
patterns.usage: Use this whenever displaying prices, sizes, or notional values to ensure they adhere to the specific exchange rules for that asset.
notes: Accepts a 'rm' (rounding mode) prop from the Decimal.js library (e.g., ROUND_UP, ROUND_DOWN).
Requires context to know which symbol's precision to apply.

patterns.name: Positions
patterns.description: A core UI component that renders a table of the user's current trading positions. It handles the display of standard position data such as symbol, size, entry price, and mark price.
patterns.usage: Use this when you need a custom layout or want to embed the positions table within your own UI container (e.g., inside a dashboard grid) without the default widget wrapper.
notes: Requires an OrderlyProvider context to fetch position data.
This component focuses purely on the data table; it does not include the outer card styling or headers found in the Widget version.

patterns.name: MobilePositions
patterns.description: A mobile-optimized list view for displaying positions. Instead of a dense table, it typically renders position data in a vertical card or expanded list format suitable for touch interfaces.
patterns.usage: Ideal for mobile-first applications or responsive layouts where the standard desktop table is too cramped.
notes: Designed for smaller viewports.
Interactions are tailored for touch (e.g., larger tap targets).

patterns.name: CombinePositions
patterns.description: Displays positions in a combined or aggregated format. This is often used to show net positions or group positions by underlying asset in cross-margin modes.
patterns.usage: Use this when you want to present a simplified view of risk exposure by combining similar positions rather than listing every individual order.
notes: Useful for portfolio overview dashboards.
