Data aggregation logic is handled internally based on the account mode.

patterns.name: PositionsWidget
patterns.description: A complete, self-contained widget that includes the header, filters, and the positions table. It is the standard 'drop-in' solution for displaying positions on a desktop trading interface.
patterns.usage: The default choice for most desktop trading interfaces. It manages its own layout and state presentation.
notes: Internal usage indicates it supports filtering by `symbol`.
Includes built-in UI for headers and action buttons.

patterns.name: MobilePositionsWidget
patterns.description: The mobile counterpart to the PositionsWidget. It wraps the mobile-optimized list view with appropriate headers and navigation controls for a mobile app experience.
patterns.usage: Best for full-screen mobile views or bottom sheets in trading apps.
notes: Handles symbol switching logic via `onSymbolChange`.
Responsive design adapts to mobile screen widths automatically.

patterns.name: CombinePositionsWidget
patterns.description: A widget wrapper for the CombinePositions component. It provides the aggregated position view within a styled container suitable for a dashboard.
patterns.usage: Use when you need the 'Combine' logic but want the consistent look and feel of other Orderly widgets.
notes: Useful for risk management views where individual order details are less important than total exposure.

patterns.name: ReversePositionWidget
patterns.description: A specialized widget that allows users to quickly reverse their position (e.g., closing a Long and opening a Short of the same size) in a single action.
patterns.usage: Ideal for advanced trading interfaces where users frequently flip their market sentiment on a specific asset.
notes: This is a high-level trading action component.
Requires valid position data to function effectively.

patterns.name: AccountSummary
patterns.description: A flexible component that renders a summary of the user's account state, such as equity, margin ratio, and PnL. It allows customization of which fields are displayed via `elementKeys`.
patterns.usage: Perfect for the top bar of a trading app or a dashboard overview card to give users a quick health check of their account.
notes: Found in `@orderly.network/ui-scaffold`.
The `elementKeys` prop maps internal data keys to display labels or determines visibility.

patterns.name: BottomNav
patterns.description: A mobile-first bottom navigation bar component used to switch between primary views in the application.
patterns.usage: Use this component to render the main navigation menu on mobile devices. It accepts an array of menu objects defining the label, icons, and click handlers.
notes: Typically fixed to the bottom of the viewport on mobile screens.
Ensure icons provided are valid React elements.
The 'mainMenus' prop is required and expects an array of menu configuration objects.

patterns.name: BottomNavWidget
patterns.description: A widget wrapper for the BottomNav component, likely providing pre-configured state or context integration.
patterns.usage: Use this when you need a drop-in navigation solution that handles internal state or routing logic automatically without manually defining menu items.
notes: This is the 'Widget' variant, implying it may connect to the Orderly store or router automatically.
Check specific SDK version for default routing behavior if props are omitted.

patterns.name: BottomNavTradingMenu
patterns.description: A specific menu item component designed for trading-related navigation within the bottom bar.
patterns.usage: Use this to render individual tabs, specifically highlighting trading states. It handles the visual distinction between active and inactive states.
notes: Requires 'active' prop to toggle styling.
Accepts separate 'icon' and 'activeIcon' props for visual feedback.
Commonly used inside the 'mainMenus' array of the BottomNav.

patterns.name: FooterWidget
patterns.description: A footer component, typically used to display legal links, social icons, or application version information.
patterns.usage: Place this at the bottom of your application layout or specific pages to provide standard footer information.
notes: Often styled with a dark theme or border separator.
Content may be static or configurable via props.

patterns.name: CloseIcon
patterns.description: A simple, reusable 'X' icon component used for closing modals, drawers, or dismissing alerts.
patterns.usage: Implement this anywhere a dismiss action is required. It supports standard SVG props like size and opacity.
notes: Supports 'size' prop to scale the icon.
Commonly used with 'className' for cursor pointer and hover effects.
Internal usage suggests 'opacity' is a controlled prop.

patterns.name: MainNavWidget
patterns.description: A navigation widget intended for desktop or main layouts, likely appearing as a sidebar or top header.
patterns.usage: Use this in desktop views to provide the primary application navigation structure.
notes: Distinct from BottomNav, usually for larger viewports.
May handle routing logic internally.

patterns.name: OfflineInfoWidget
patterns.description: A component that monitors network connectivity and displays an indicator or message when the application is offline.
patterns.usage: Include this in your root layout to ensure users are aware of connectivity issues affecting trading data.
notes: Crucial for real-time trading applications.
Likely listens to window 'online' and 'offline' events.

patterns.name: MobileScaffold
patterns.description: A layout wrapper component specifically designed for mobile views, handling header, footer, and content area positioning.
patterns.usage: Wrap your mobile pages with this component to ensure consistent layout structure, spacing, and scroll behavior.
notes: Accepts 'header' and 'footer' props to inject navigation bars.
Manages the viewport height and scrolling internally.
Essential for maintaining the 'app-like' feel on mobile browsers.

patterns.name: DesktopScaffold
patterns.description: A layout wrapper specifically designed for desktop views. It structures the application grid, handling the positioning of the sidebar, header, and main content area without requiring manual layout configuration.
patterns.usage: Wrap your root application component or specific desktop-only routes with DesktopScaffold to ensure consistent layout structure.
notes: Typically used internally by the main Scaffold component but can be used for custom desktop layouts.
Ensure the parent container has a defined height if using in a specific viewport.

patterns.name: Scaffold
patterns.description: The main application shell component that combines the sidebar, header, and footer. It provides a ready-to-use layout for decentralized exchange applications.
patterns.usage: Use this as the outermost layout component in your application to provide consistent navigation and branding.
notes: Accepts `footerProps` to configure social media links and custom footer elements.
Automatically integrates with the ScaffoldProvider for state management.

patterns.name: ScaffoldProvider
patterns.description: Context provider that manages the global state of the application scaffold, such as sidebar expansion state and routing integration.
patterns.usage: Wrap your entire application (or the part containing the Scaffold) with this provider to enable navigation and layout state control.
notes: Requires a `routerAdapter` prop to bridge the UI with your routing library (e.g., React Router).
Controls the `expanded` state of the sidebar, allowing you to programmatically toggle it.

patterns.name: SideNavbarWidget
patterns.description: The sidebar navigation widget containing links to different sections of the app like Trade, Portfolio, and History.
patterns.usage: Often used within the Scaffold layout, but can be extracted for custom layout implementations requiring a standalone sidebar.
notes: Usually reads active route from the ScaffoldProvider context.
Styling is typically handled by the parent container or the widget itself.

patterns.name: SubAccountUI
patterns.description: A UI component for managing and switching between sub-accounts. It renders a dropdown or modal interface triggered by a custom element.
patterns.usage: Place in the header or settings area to allow users to select different trading sub-accounts.
notes: The `customTrigger` prop allows you to fully customize the button that opens the account selection menu.
Requires account data context to function correctly.

patterns.name: Dot
patterns.description: A simple indicator dot component, commonly used in carousels or pagination to show the currently active item.
patterns.usage: Map over an array of items to render a dot for each, passing the `active` boolean to highlight the current selection.
notes: Accepts an `onClick` handler to make the dots interactive.
Styling changes based on the `active` prop (e.g., filled vs. outline).

patterns.name: PriceInput
patterns.description: A specialized input field for entering order prices. It handles logic for both Market and Limit order types and displays Best Bid/Offer (BBO) data.
patterns.usage: Use in order entry forms to capture the price from the user, providing context about the current market price.
notes: When `order_type` is 'MARKET', the input is typically disabled or displays 'Market'.
The `bbo` prop is used to display price hints or spread information.

patterns.name: TPSL
patterns.description: A comprehensive UI component for setting Take Profit and Stop Loss orders. It provides inputs for trigger prices and calculates estimated returns.
patterns.usage: Integrate into position management modals or trading views to allow users to set risk management parameters for their positions.
notes: Requires position context (symbol, side, size) to calculate valid price ranges.
The `onComplete` callback is triggered when the user confirms the TP/SL settings.

patterns.name: TPSLWidget
patterns.description: A widget component used to manage Take Profit (TP) and Stop Loss (SL) settings for a specific trading position. It typically handles the logic for calculating trigger prices and executing orders based on the position type (Long/Short).
patterns.usage: Use this component in position management modals or sidebars to allow users to define risk management parameters for an existing trade.
notes: Requires position context (symbol, positionType) to function correctly.
Often used within a larger position details view.

patterns.name: TPSLSimpleDialogUI
patterns.description: The UI-only presentation layer for a simplified Take Profit/Stop Loss dialog. It renders the form fields and buttons but relies on parent components for state management and logic execution.
patterns.usage: Useful when building a custom TP/SL flow where you need full control over the dialog state and logic, but want to reuse Orderly's standardized visual design.
notes: This is a 'UI' component, meaning it is primarily presentational.
Requires callbacks for `close`, `onComplete`, and navigation to advanced views.

patterns.name: TPSLSimpleDialogWidget
patterns.description: A fully functional widget wrapper for the simplified TP/SL dialog. It encapsulates both the UI (TPSLSimpleDialogUI) and the business logic required to fetch position data and submit TP/SL orders.
patterns.usage: Ideal for quick integration where a standard 'Set TP/SL' interaction is needed without building custom state logic.
notes: No internal usages found in the provided context, suggesting it is a standalone entry point.
Likely handles API calls internally via the Orderly provider.

patterns.name: DesktopDisplayControl
patterns.description: A desktop-specific control bar for the TradingView chart interface. It provides buttons to toggle various chart display settings like indicators, drawing tools, or chart types.
patterns.usage: Place this in the header or toolbar of a desktop trading view to give users control over their chart environment.
notes: Designed specifically for desktop layouts.
Often paired with other chart controls like TimeInterval.

patterns.name: MobileDisplayControl
patterns.description: A mobile-optimized version of the display control component. It adapts the chart settings functionality for smaller screens, often using icons or condensed menus.
patterns.usage: Implement in the mobile view of your trading interface to save space while retaining chart customization capabilities.
notes: Ensure responsive layout handling when switching between Desktop and Mobile versions.
Touch-friendly targets.

patterns.name: TimeInterval
patterns.description: A component that allows users to select the time interval (timeframe) for the chart, such as 1 minute, 1 hour, or 1 day.
patterns.usage: Standard component for the top toolbar of a trading chart to switch between different analysis timeframes.
notes: Usually syncs with the TradingView widget's chart resolution.
Visual style typically matches the active theme.

patterns.name: MobileTimeInterval
patterns.description: A mobile-adapted selector for chart time intervals. It may render as a horizontal scrollable list or a dropdown to accommodate mobile UI constraints.
patterns.usage: Used in mobile trading views to allow timeframe switching without consuming excessive screen real estate.
notes: Optimized for touch scrolling or tapping.
Often displays fewer interval options than desktop by default.

patterns.name: ZoomOutIcon
patterns.description: A simple icon component representing a 'Zoom Out' action. It is typically used within chart toolbars to trigger a zoom-out event on the TradingView chart.
patterns.usage: Place inside a chart control bar. Attach an `onClick` handler that calls the TradingView widget's `execAction()` method or similar zoom logic.
notes: Internal usage shows it accepts standard className props for styling.
Usually part of a set of zoom controls (ZoomIn, Reset).

patterns.name: ZoomInIcon
patterns.description: A presentational icon component used within trading chart interfaces to trigger a zoom-in action. It typically inherits text colors for styling and handles hover states.
patterns.usage: Use this in chart toolbars or control panels where users need to magnify the view of a trading chart.
notes: Accepts standard SVG/HTML attributes like className and onClick.
Often paired with ZoomOutIcon.
Uses Orderly utility classes (oui-*) for consistent theming.

patterns.name: LtvUI
patterns.description: A UI component designed to display the Loan-to-Value (LTV) ratio. It provides a visual representation of the user's current debt relative to their collateral.
patterns.usage: Ideal for dashboard cards or margin account summaries where users need a quick check of their liquidation risk.
notes: Primarily a display component, not interactive.
Props typically include the current value and the maximum safe threshold.
May render a progress bar or colored text based on risk level.

patterns.name: LtvWidget
patterns.description: An advanced widget for displaying Loan-to-Value that supports showing projections or differences (e.g., how LTV changes after a borrow or repay action).
patterns.usage: Use in modals or forms where the user is adjusting their position (borrowing/repaying) and needs to see the impact on their LTV in real-time.
notes: The 'showDiff' prop controls whether the delta between current and new LTV is visible.
Essential for risk management during transfer or trading operations.
Often updates dynamically based on input fields.

patterns.name: AccountSelect
patterns.description: A dropdown selector component allowing users to choose between different accounts (e.g., Trading Account, sub-accounts) for transfers or allocations.
patterns.usage: Used in transfer flows to select the source or destination of funds.
notes: Requires an array of account objects for 'subAccounts'.
Controlled component: requires 'value' and 'onValueChange' props.
Integrates with the broader transfer state management.

patterns.name: ActionButton
patterns.description: A multi-purpose button that adapts its appearance and behavior based on the user's state (connected, trading enabled) or the specific action being performed (deposit, withdraw).
patterns.usage: The primary call-to-action button in transfer modals and trading forms.
notes: Handles complex logic internally, such as checking if trading is enabled.
Props like 'actionType' and 'symbol' customize the button text and icon.
Can be disabled based on validation logic.

patterns.name: ChainSelect
patterns.description: A dropdown component for selecting the blockchain network. Used to filter assets or set the destination for cross-chain operations.
patterns.usage: Essential in cross-chain transfer interfaces or when filtering assets by network.
notes: Expects an array of chain objects containing 'chainId' and 'name'.
Controlled component requiring 'value' and 'onValueChange'.
Usually displays network icons alongside names.

patterns.name: CollateralContribution
patterns.description: An input field specifically designed for entering collateral amounts. It handles precision formatting (e.g., for USDC) and validation against available balances.
patterns.usage: Used in margin management forms where users add or remove collateral to their positions.
notes: Takes a 'precision' prop to ensure decimal accuracy for specific tokens.
Often includes a 'Max' button functionality internally.
Visual feedback for insufficient balance.

patterns.name: CollateralRatioUI
patterns.description: A UI component that displays the collateral ratio, indicating the health of a margin account. It often changes color based on whether the ratio is safe or close to liquidation.
patterns.usage: Used in account summaries and risk panels to give users an immediate sense of their account safety.
notes: Display-only component.
Likely accepts a 'status' prop (e.g., 'safe', 'warning', 'danger') to trigger color changes.
Complements LtvUI by showing the inverse metric.

patterns.name: CollateralRatioWidget
patterns.description: A visual widget that displays the user's collateral ratio (health factor). It typically visualizes the ratio as a progress bar or gauge, indicating how close the account is to liquidation.
patterns.usage: Use this in portfolio or account overview sections to give users a quick visual indication of their margin account health.
notes: The value prop usually expects a number (e.g., 1.5 for 150%).
The component handles the visual color coding (e.g., green for safe, red for danger) based on the value internally.

patterns.name: ConvertAction
patterns.description: A button component specifically designed for triggering token conversions or swaps. It handles loading and disabled states visually.
patterns.usage: Place this at the bottom of a conversion form. It connects the user's intent to the conversion logic.
notes: Requires the `networkId` to ensure the transaction is broadcast to the correct chain.
The `loading` prop automatically disables the button and shows a spinner.

patterns.name: ConvertFormUI
patterns.description: A 'dumb' UI component that renders the inputs for a token conversion. It manages the layout of 'From' and 'To' fields but does not handle price fetching or transaction execution logic itself.
patterns.usage: Use this when you need full control over the state management and logic of the conversion form, but want to use Orderly's standard design.
notes: This is a presentational component. You must manage the state (amounts, selected tokens) in the parent component.
Requires props for token metadata (symbol, decimals) and current amounts.

patterns.name: ConvertFormWidget
patterns.description: A fully functional 'smart' widget for token conversion. It wraps the ConvertFormUI and handles internal state, price fetching, and validation automatically.
patterns.usage: The quickest way to add conversion functionality to your app without building the underlying logic.
notes: Handles API calls to fetch conversion rates internally.
Takes initial token symbols or addresses as props to pre-fill the form.

patterns.name: DepositStatus
patterns.description: A presentational component that displays the status of a deposit transaction (e.g., Pending, Success, Failed).
patterns.usage: Use this inside modals or dedicated status pages to inform the user about the progress of their transfer.
notes: Accepts a status string/enum to determine the icon and color scheme.
Does not fetch status; it only displays what is passed to it.

patterns.name: DepositStatusWidget
patterns.description: A 'smart' widget that tracks and displays the status of an ongoing deposit. It typically includes logic to check transaction status and provides navigation actions.
patterns.usage: Ideal for placing on a dashboard or deposit page where the user needs to see the result of their last action.
notes: Often includes a button or link to view the transaction details or portfolio.
Manages its own data fetching regarding the deposit state.

patterns.name: MinimumReceived
patterns.description: A small text component that displays the minimum amount a user will receive after a conversion, accounting for slippage.
patterns.usage: Place this near the 'Convert' button to ensure transparency about price impact and slippage tolerance.
notes: Requires the token symbol and precision to format the number correctly.
Helps meet UI requirements for decentralized exchange interfaces.

patterns.name: DepositProvider
patterns.description: A React Context Provider that supplies deposit-related state and functionality (like checking balances, initiating transfers) to its children components.
patterns.usage: Wrap your application or a specific section of your trading interface with this provider to enable deposit features in child widgets.
notes: Necessary for 'smart' widgets like DepositStatusWidget to function correctly.
Abstracts away the complex logic of interacting with broker wallets and the Orderly chain.

patterns.name: TokenOption
patterns.description: A selectable list item component used within token input fields or dropdowns. It displays the token's icon, symbol, and optionally fetches and displays the user's balance.
patterns.usage: Use this component when building a custom token selector dropdown or a list of available assets for transfer/swap. It handles the visual distinction between active (selected) and inactive states.
notes: The `displayType` prop controls whether the balance is shown or hidden.
Ensure the `token` object follows the standard Orderly `Token` interface.
The `fetchBalance` function is asynchronous and should return a string representation of the balance.

patterns.name: SwapDepositProvider
patterns.description: A Context Provider that manages the state and logic for Swapping and Depositing assets. It wraps child components to provide them with necessary data like selected tokens, amounts, and transaction handlers.
patterns.usage: Wrap your main transfer or swap interface component with this provider. It is essential for enabling the internal logic of swap and deposit forms within the `@orderly.network/ui-transfer` ecosystem.
notes: This component does not render any UI itself; it acts as a state container.
It is required when using complex swap components that rely on shared context.
Place it high in the component tree to ensure all child components have access to token state.

patterns.name: SwapIndicator
patterns.description: A visual UI component that indicates the direction of a swap between two tokens. It typically renders an arrow or icon and allows the user to click to switch the source and target tokens.
patterns.usage: Place this component between the 'From' and 'To' input fields in a swap interface. It provides visual feedback and interaction for reversing the trade pair.
notes: The `sourceToken` and `targetToken` props are usually strings representing symbols (e.g., 'ETH').
You can pass an `onSwap` callback to handle the logic of switching token values in your parent state.
Styling can be customized via the `className` prop.

patterns.name: WithdrawForm
patterns.description: A comprehensive form component designed for handling withdrawals. It includes inputs for the amount, destination address, and chain selection, along with validation and submission logic.
patterns.usage: Use this component to create a withdrawal interface. It encapsulates the complexity of gathering withdrawal data from the user, including network selection and address validation.

patterns.description: A conditional warning component that displays messages to the user based on the state of their withdrawal request. It checks for conditions like bridgeless transfers, cross-chain transactions, or excessive quantities.
